para.paratext: There is no general physician-patient evidentiary privilege recognized under federal or Georgia law.[1] However, Congress and the Georgia General Assembly have both enacted patient privacy legislation. The federal law is known as the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA).[2] HIPAA precludes a health-care provider from using or disclosing “protected health information” except as permitted by its privacy regulations. HIPAA does not create state or federal evidentiary privileges.[3]

Georgia public policy supported codifying a patient's right to privacy.[4] The current statutes do not create any type of general evidentiary privilege for doctor-patient communications. The first of these statutes is O.C.G.A. § 24-12-1, which states that a physician cannot be required to release medical information concerning a patient except in specified situations. Although O.C.G.A. § 24-12-1 is referred to in terms of “privilege,” it is in reality a “physician shield statute,” which compels disclosure of medical information upon proper order and offers protection to the physician from adverse action by the patient when such information is properly released.[5] O.C.G.A. §§ 24-12-10 to 24-12-14 likewise limit the disclosure of a patient's medical records, and O.C.G.A. § 24-12-21 makes certain AIDS information disclosed or discovered within the physician-patient relationship is confidential. Likewise, the courts in Georgia have held that the psychiatrist-patient privilege does not yield to a defendant's constitutional right of confrontation where the defendant is seeking the psychological records of a victim in a mere “fishing expedition.”[6] Moreover, the psychiatrist-patient privilege survives the death of the patient. The patient's representative cannot waive the privilege, nor can privileged records be released to them.[7] The privilege extends even where medical malpractice actions are thwarted by the next of kin's inability to obtain the medical records.[8]

In Moreland v. Austin,[9] the Georgia Supreme Court held that Georgia's law providing that, once the plaintiff puts his medical condition in issue in a civil or criminal proceeding, the defendant can seek the plaintiff's protected health information by formal discovery or informally by communicating orally with plaintiff's physicians was preempted by the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act.[10] Accordingly, HIPAA now governs ex parte communications between defense counsel and health care providers in Georgia and is more stringent than state law, which was not designed to protect patient's private health information in the course of oral communications between patient's physicians and defense counsel.[11]

However, Georgia's law must still be complied with even when the procedural requirements of HIPAA are met. Though HIPAA preempts Georgia law in its imposition of procedural requirements, the substantive right to medical privacy under Georgia law endures.[12] For example, a qualified protective order, as required by HIPAA, must comply with Georgia's law limiting a patient's waiver of privacy to the extent such information is relevant to the medical condition the litigant has placed in issue in the legal proceeding.[13] Moreover, the court does not commit error by allowing the testimony of psychotherapist at trial regarding a defendant's mental capacity, where the defendant has placed his mental capacity at issue.[14] Overly broad qualified protective orders are considered deficient, even if in compliance with HIPAA.[15]

See Elliott v. Georgia Power Co., 58 Ga. App. 151, 197 S.E. 914 (1938); Orr v. Sievert, 162 Ga. App. 677, 292 S.E.2d 548 (1982); see also Gilmore v. State, 175 Ga. App. 376, 333 S.E.2d 210 (1985) (confirming absence of privilege); National Stop Smoking Clinic-Atlanta, Inc. v. Dean, 190 Ga. App. 289, 378 S.E.2d 901 (1989) (same).
There is likewise no evidentiary privilege for communications between a hospital and patient. See Dennis v. Adcock, 138 Ga. App. 425, 226 S.E.2d 292 (1976).

[I]n issuing orders authorizing ex parte interviews, trial courts should state with particularity: (1) the names of the health care providers who may be interviewed; (2) the medical conditions at issue in the litigation regarding which the health care providers may be interviewed; (3) the fact that the interview is at the request of the defendant, not the patient-plaintiff, and is for the purpose of assisting defense counsel in the litigation; and (4) the fact that the health care provider's participation in the interview is voluntary.
